pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: Is anything publishing on the `~/selection/server` topic?
content.html: Is anything publishing on the ~/selection/server topic?

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
An inspection of default branch:

```
jackie@pol:~/code/gazebo/gazebo$ rgrep "~/selection"
rendering/Scene.cc:  this->dataPtr->selectionSub = this->dataPtr->node->Subscribe("~/selection",
gui/GLWidget_TEST.cc:  sub = node->Subscribe("~/selection", &OnSelection, this);
gui/GLWidget.cc:  this->selectionSub = this->node->Subscribe("~/selection",
gui/GLWidget.cc:    this->node->Advertise<msgs::Selection>("~/selection");
```
The only class that advertises on `~/selection` is `GLWidget` itself. `Scene` and `GLWidget` both subscribe to `~/selection`. This means that `GLWidget` is publishing to `Scene` and to other `GLWidget`s. This PR differentiates between the topic `GLWidget` publishes to and the topic it subscribes to.

Since nobody else publishes to `~/selection`, nobody needs to publish to `~/selection/server` in this PR.

I believe the reason this line is here is so that an external publisher can affect changes in the selection state by publishing to `~/selection` (or `~/selection/server` with this change). However, it does not appear to be tested in Gazebo (`rgrep ~/selection` in `gazebo/test`, `gazebo/plugins`, `gazebo/examples`). I could potentially add a test for this feature to `GLWidget` in this PR.
content.html:
An inspection of default branch:

jackie@pol:~/code/gazebo/gazebo$ rgrep "~/selection"
rendering/Scene.cc:  this->dataPtr->selectionSub = this->dataPtr->node->Subscribe("~/selection",
gui/GLWidget_TEST.cc:  sub = node->Subscribe("~/selection", &OnSelection, this);
gui/GLWidget.cc:  this->selectionSub = this->node->Subscribe("~/selection",
gui/GLWidget.cc:    this->node->Advertise<msgs::Selection>("~/selection");

The only class that advertises on ~/selection is GLWidget itself. Scene and GLWidget both subscribe to ~/selection. This means that GLWidget is publishing to Scene and to other GLWidgets. This PR differentiates between the topic GLWidget publishes to and the topic it subscribes to.

Since nobody else publishes to ~/selection, nobody needs to publish to ~/selection/server in this PR.

I believe the reason this line is here is so that an external publisher can affect changes in the selection state by publishing to ~/selection (or ~/selection/server with this change). However, it does not appear to be tested in Gazebo (rgrep ~/selection in gazebo/test, gazebo/plugins, gazebo/examples). I could potentially add a test for this feature to GLWidget in this PR.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: If I understand this right, this will change the selection behavior. Currently if you select an object in a single gzclient, it will try to select that object in all other `gzclient` instances. Here you are proposing that selections in a single `gzclient` should not affect other `gzclient`'s. That makes sense to me, in case you want to inspect different models in each `gzclient` instance.
content.html: If I understand this right, this will change the selection behavior. Currently if you select an object in a single gzclient, it will try to select that object in all other gzclient instances. Here you are proposing that selections in a single gzclient should not affect other gzclient's. That makes sense to me, in case you want to inspect different models in each gzclient instance.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: Agreed, I think selection in one gzclient should not effect the selection state of another gzclient. This PR reverts the behavior of selection with multiple gzclients back to gazebo_4.1 and lower, where selecting an object in one gzclient does not affect another.
content.html: Agreed, I think selection in one gzclient should not effect the selection state of another gzclient. This PR reverts the behavior of selection with multiple gzclients back to gazebo_4.1 and lower, where selecting an object in one gzclient does not affect another.

@iche033 Is this because the clients are using the same name for ogre resources?

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
There are a couple problems with this pull request:

1. This hides issue #1523, but does not fix it. Gzclient should not crash if two clients try to select a light.

1. Gazebo 4.1 subscribed to `~/selection`, not `~/selection/server`.  If gazebo 4.1 really did not have the problem of cross-client selection, then the problem lies elsewhere.

1. I have significant doubt about this fixing pr 1506. Even if it does, then it's hiding a deeper problem.
content.html:
There are a couple problems with this pull request:

  1. This hides issue #1523, but does not fix it. Gzclient should not crash if two clients try to select a light.

  2. Gazebo 4.1 subscribed to ~/selection, not ~/selection/server. If gazebo 4.1 really did not have the problem of cross-client selection, then the problem lies elsewhere.

  3. I have significant doubt about this fixing pr 1506. Even if it does, then it's hiding a deeper problem.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
1. This is not a complete fix for #1523; it is a workaround and I can edit my prior descriptions to say so. It is, however, a fix for the problem where changing the selection state in one client affects the selection state of another. If you do not think this is a problem, we should discuss that further. A complete fix for #1523 would probably be to change the underlying problem of Ogre `HardwareVertexBuffer` logic.

2. Gazebo 4.1 does indeed subscribe to `~/selection`. The problem is that `GLWidget` in gazebo5 and higher also publishes to `~/selection` when an object gets selected. This causes behavior where changing selection state in one gzclient affects the selection state of another.

3. Some of the crashes in PR 1506 originate from `OnSelectionMsg` (see [Louise's backtrace](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1506/apply-force-torque-gui/diff#comment-5749172)). The idea behind my (admittedly thin) connection to PR 1506 is that reducing spurious calls to `OnSelectionMsg` will reduce number of occurrences of the event where the crashes originate.

If you think changing the name of the topic advertised by `GLWidget` is too simplistic a solution for the problem of multiple gzclients then feel free to propose a stronger alternative.
content.html:
1. This is not a complete fix for #1523; it is a workaround and I can edit my prior descriptions to say so. It is, however, a fix for the problem where changing the selection state in one client affects the selection state of another. If you do not think this is a problem, we should discuss that further. A complete fix for #1523 would probably be to change the underlying problem of Ogre HardwareVertexBuffer logic.

  2. Gazebo 4.1 does indeed subscribe to ~/selection. The problem is that GLWidget in gazebo5 and higher also publishes to ~/selection when an object gets selected. This causes behavior where changing selection state in one gzclient affects the selection state of another.

  3. Some of the crashes in PR 1506 originate from OnSelectionMsg (see Louise's backtrace). The idea behind my (admittedly thin) connection to PR 1506 is that reducing spurious calls to OnSelectionMsg will reduce number of occurrences of the event where the crashes originate.

If you think changing the name of the topic advertised by GLWidget is too simplistic a solution for the problem of multiple gzclients then feel free to propose a stronger alternative.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: I suggest declining this pull request, and looking for alternative solutions to issue #1523, the problem in pull request 1506, and also the problem of cross-client selection. Changing the subscription topic name in GLWidget is not a good solution because the problem was not introduced here, and it changes behavior that has existed for a long time.
content.html: I suggest declining this pull request, and looking for alternative solutions to issue #1523, the problem in pull request 1506, and also the problem of cross-client selection. Changing the subscription topic name in GLWidget is not a good solution because the problem was not introduced here, and it changes behavior that has existed for a long time.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: I don't think anyone is publishing to the `~/selection` topic in gazebo 4.1 so we haven't encountered this problem. To test this I just manaully published a message to `~/selection` topic in gazebo 4.1 and gzclient also crashes
content.html: I don't think anyone is publishing to the ~/selection topic in gazebo 4.1 so we haven't encountered this problem. To test this I just manaully published a message to ~/selection topic in gazebo 4.1 and gzclient also crashes

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: Actually, `World` creates a publisher for `~/selection` in `gazebo_4.1` (see [source](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/dbeb8b56014898424ccbd84046282b2ecaaf7f81/gazebo/physics/World.cc?at=gazebo_4.1#cl-216)). That publisher was taken out in [PR1318](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1318/publish-model-selection). But considering that your test makes gzclient crash, I'm guessing that the selection message publication in `World` is dead code.
content.html: Actually, World creates a publisher for ~/selection in gazebo_4.1 (see source). That publisher was taken out in PR1318. But considering that your test makes gzclient crash, I'm guessing that the selection message publication in World is dead code.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
I made a fix in [issue_1523_gazebo5_ian](#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/3a5fd0e2dc463cfbccbf71a908c0143c44566666). It's mainly a threading issue and the changes in my branch ensure that the selection msgs are processed in the main rendering thread. Selection across multiple gzclients should now work and any one should be able to publish to the `~/selection` topic. 

On the other hand - I am not sure about the behavior of model selection one gzclient highlighting the model in another client though. I feel that users may not necessary want that.
content.html:
I made a fix in issue_1523_gazebo5_ian. It's mainly a threading issue and the changes in my branch ensure that the selection msgs are processed in the main rendering thread. Selection across multiple gzclients should now work and any one should be able to publish to the ~/selection topic.

On the other hand - I am not sure about the behavior of model selection one gzclient highlighting the model in another client though. I feel that users may not necessary want that.

content.html: I agree, I would think that clicking in one gzclient wouldn't change the selected object in a separate instance. cc: @spaepcke

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: It's possible to open two copies of the `gzclient` GUI window for a single world (`gzserver` instance). Currently, when you select an object in one window, it will try to select that object in the other window as well. It's a bit of cross-talk between the windows. I would expect selecting an object in one window to not change the selection status in the other window.
content.html: It's possible to open two copies of the gzclient GUI window for a single world (gzserver instance). Currently, when you select an object in one window, it will try to select that object in the other window as well. It's a bit of cross-talk between the windows. I would expect selecting an object in one window to not change the selection status in the other window.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
Ok, that's what I suspected, thanks. Let's say I have an object selected in one window, then you select a different object in your window. My selection would switch to be your selection? If that's the case, agreed that this should not happen. 

At the same time, it would be a little confusing if the object you selected (and translated, for example) suddenly popped up in a different location in my window. I would have no prior indication that someone was also active on "my" gzserver. This is probably too much for this PR, but I wonder if we could take a cue from Google Docs and have your selection appear in my window, but in a different color, or with some alternate styling. Then I'd know you're there and I'd anticipate things changing in some way.
content.html:
Ok, that's what I suspected, thanks. Let's say I have an object selected in one window, then you select a different object in your window. My selection would switch to be your selection? If that's the case, agreed that this should not happen.

At the same time, it would be a little confusing if the object you selected (and translated, for example) suddenly popped up in a different location in my window. I would have no prior indication that someone was also active on "my" gzserver. This is probably too much for this PR, but I wonder if we could take a cue from Google Docs and have your selection appear in my window, but in a different color, or with some alternate styling. Then I'd know you're there and I'd anticipate things changing in some way.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
I like this solution, although I'm not sure about having a global vector of points to selection messages... When we target the solution to `default` we can make the storage data structure a class member of GLWidget.

As far as model selection behavior goes, I think we can resolve it in a different PR/make a new issue. It will take some more forethought if we are not permitted to change the topic name.
content.html:
I like this solution, although I'm not sure about having a global vector of points to selection messages... When we target the solution to default we can make the storage data structure a class member of GLWidget.

As far as model selection behavior goes, I think we can resolve it in a different PR/make a new issue. It will take some more forethought if we are not permitted to change the topic name.

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: ya I used a global variable in order to keep ABI compatibility..
content.html: ya I used a global variable in order to keep ABI compatibility..

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw:
We should not completely swap out code in an active pull request. In the future, please submit a new pull-request.

For the changes proposed here, adding this to the render loop is not ideal. Can you instead trigger a thread safe qt connection when a selection message is received?
content.html:
We should not completely swap out code in an active pull request. In the future, please submit a new pull-request.

For the changes proposed here, adding this to the render loop is not ideal. Can you instead trigger a thread safe qt connection when a selection message is received?

content.html: I implemented the solution; it works but it breaks ABI. Should I retarget to default?

pullrequest.title: issue #1523: process selection msgs in qt connection event in GLWidget

content.raw: A `Qt::QueuedConnection` is needed to be thread safe. See [here](Qt::QueuedConnection)
content.html: A Qt::QueuedConnection is needed to be thread safe. See here
